repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This allows filtering captures that are not useful, and provides a severe performance boost when handling long lines.

cc @bfredl.

---
### Updates from @lewis6991 

Todo:
- [ ] Handle conceal

comment_data.body: let's exclude this. the end column is harder to calculate and will depend on the line (so if we do it later on, it is gonna be in the "line" event).
Exclude the end column you mean ?
is this really correct? what happens with `set linebreak` ?
The CI seems to indicate that it works, is it well tested already ?
don't expect CI to contain broken lines, excessive unicode, etc in places where it didn't matter yet :D

As I said in chat before, this is a perf regression, as you now need to retraverse the tree from the root on each line . What we possibly could do is to ask TS to add a method to _skip_ a range in a cursor (i e don't descend into irrelevant subtrees).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -241,19 +240,17 @@ local function on_line_impl(self, buf, line)
     -- Some injected languages may not have highlight queries.
     if not highlighter_query:query() then return end
 
-    if state.iter == nil then
-      state.iter = highlighter_query:query():iter_captures(root_node, self.bufnr, line, root_end_row + 1)
-    end
+    local iter = highlighter_query:query():iter_captures(root_node, self.bufnr, line, root_end_row + 1, leftcol, rightcol)

comment_data.body: Oh sorry about that, let me remove it
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -241,19 +240,17 @@ local function on_line_impl(self, buf, line)
     -- Some injected languages may not have highlight queries.
     if not highlighter_query:query() then return end
 
-    if state.iter == nil then
-      state.iter = highlighter_query:query():iter_captures(root_node, self.bufnr, line, root_end_row + 1)
-    end
+    local iter = highlighter_query:query():iter_captures(root_node, self.bufnr, line, root_end_row + 1, leftcol, rightcol)

comment_data.body: this function takes a byte count and returns a screen width, so this cannot be right.
In the tests I did, it seems that is returns a correct value everytime, even with `wrap` on.
Though with `linebreak` this seems to be a little borked
Bascically I want to compute the amount of text of this line that I am going to see on the screen
Even with non-ASCII characters present? What about if the line contains `brk brk brk` or `bire` (or, more likely, ``)?
don't forget unprintable chars, hard tabstops, conceals, etc etc.

comment_regular_data.body: This has been closed since a request for information has not been answered for 30 days. It can be reopened when the requested information is provided.
